awd_titl_txt: Strategies for Co-existence of  Radio Telescope Arrays with Broadcast Stations and Wireless Communication Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This EARS (Enhancing Access to the Radio Spectrum) program was founded in response to the 2010 Presidential Memorandum on Unleashing the Wireless Broadband Revolution mandated by Congress as part of the National Broadband Plan. It was referenced in 2010 State of the Union and later on the Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012 (More than 1/3 of the bill deals with radio spectrum), the PCAST 2012 Report [President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology] (which calls for vastly increased use of spectrum sharing) and the 2013 Presidential memo (Expanding America's Leadership in Wireless Innovation). The aim of this program is to identify bold new concepts with the potential to contribute to significant improvements in the efficiency of radio spectrum utilization, protection of passive sensing services, and in the ability for traditionally underserved Americans to benefit from current and future wireless-enabled goods and services. The impact is large on the economics of the Nation as seen on the last FCC bidding of 65MHz of the spectrum for over $45 billion early in 2015. It will enable access to science, engineering, industry, civilian and military users of the radio frequency (RF) spectrum.

Demand for wireless broadband has soared due to technological innovation, such as 4G mobile services, and the rapid increase in wireless internet. This demand would require the utilization of frequencies over a bandwidth that has been traditionally slated for radio telescopes. This frequency infringement may interfere with reception and interpretation of astronomical data and, as such, compromise the search and discoveries of extraterrestrial intelligence. The project puts forward coexistence strategies where wireless users cause minimum interference to astronomical observations. 

The project aims at achieving the coexistence strategies by developing interference mitigation techniques that factor in the high-elevation of the look direction of the telescope compared to low-elevation angles of signals emitted by base-stations and wireless systems. A co-existence strategy calls for authorized broadcast stations and wireless transmitters to cooperate with radio telescopes by reporting their locations and providing properties of their signal structures. Prior knowledge of interference location simplifies its nulling and removal by telescope array of multiple units. On the other hand, the distinction in signal characteristics between astronomical events and those of digital communications enables effective cooperative as well as non-cooperative interference identification and suppression.  The project has the potential to advance spectrum sharing and utilization and therefore enhance the future capacity for U.S. industry and academic institutions in this area of research and development.

por.por_cntn:
The project considered co-existence between radio frequency (RF) systems which has become essential to alleviate the competition between different RF services and sensing platforms over scarce spectrum. Passive sensing includes radio telescopes where the system does not emit signals but rather comprises an array of telescope receivers to gather extraterrestrial signal emissions from the sky. On the other hand, active sensing includes radar in which target detection and ranging are achieved by processing the emitted signal returns after backscattering from stationary and moving targets. Wireless communication, in particular cellular telephony, uses RF signals to transmit information from one transceiver phone to another through the wireless channel and with the help of base stations. Other RF services include satellite navigation systems, like GPS, and telemetry. 

The project main objective was to develop techniques and methodologies as well as system design and integration approaches to combat mutual interference that arises when these RF services overlap in frequency and share common or partial bandwidth. The focus was on bandwidth competitions between wireless communications and both radio telescopes and radar. Because astronomical signals are extremely weak and span a broad frequency spectrum determined by the astronomical objects, effective interference cancellation is vital to protect astronomical signal observation from a growing number of terrestrial RF signals. The project developed new signal processing methodologies that enable effective interference cancellation for radio astronomy and in a broader context of RF system co-existence through spatial and time-frequency domain filtering.

For spatial domain filtering, robust beamforming techniques were developed based on accurate estimation of the actual signal steering vector and interference covariance matrix to effectively cancel signals that interfere with radio astronomical signal reception and avoid self-nulling of desired signals. Hence, providing a high signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR), even under imperfect array manifold calibration. To further enhance the interference cancellation capability, sparse array designs and signal processing techniques were developed that achieve large array apertures and increased degrees of freedom for improved interference cancellation and desired signal enhancement.

In order to eliminate the interference, or substantially reduce its power, time-frequency signal representation was employed to reveal the interference signature in the joint-variable domain.  Sparsity-based time-frequency analysis was applied to provide accurate instantaneous frequency estimation, and thus correct interference characterization, even when the measurements are severely impaired with fading and missing signal samples. The time-frequency domain sparsity of various frequency modulated and frequency-hopping signals was exploited to enable time-frequency signature recovery and instantaneous frequency estimation techniques through sparsity time-frequency signature reconstruction and structured Hankel matrix completion of the stationary instantaneous autocorrelation functions.    

For RF co-existence between radar and communications, the project pursued different strategies where the communication signals modulate the radar beams or the radar signals, an approach leading to what is referred to as dual-function radar-communication (DFRC) systems. Various approaches to DFRC system design, including downlink and uplink signaling schemes, were devised along with their respective design requirements, offerings, and challenges. Most importantly, the project provided comprehensive analysis of the DFRC system, including achievable communication data rates and radar performance loss assessment due to resource sharing and system parameter modifications and alterations.

Towards the co-use of the system RF aperture for dual functions, the project put forward several aperture designs that accommodate radar and communication objectives, specifically providing high SINR. The latter is fundamental to high quality of service in wireless connectivity and is also essential for target detection and tracking. The project considered sparse array design where antenna placements are selected to optimize the intended performance. The optimization problem involved multiple constraints on aperture size, number of antennas, and antenna spacing, and was formed to handle narrowband and wideband types of signals. Methods for reconfiguring the array and adjusting its coefficients, as environment changes in source and interference, were developed utilizing recent advances in antenna switching technologies as well as advances in convex optimizations. Machine learning was also used to render the most appropriate antenna locations in one-dimensional and two-dimensional configurations which maintain high SINR in time-varying environments.
